Although ammonia is a listed toxic substance, it is also a ubiquitous material, which is used by farmers for fertilizer. Pursuant to 40 CFR 68.125 Exemptions ¿ Ammonia used as an agricultural nutrient, when held by farmers, is exempt from all provisions of this part (40 CFR 68).

III.	Facility Identification
The Otto & Sons facility is located at 4545 South Racine Avenue in Chicago, Illinois. The facility processes ready to cook and fully cooked bacon and processes and packages chili, beans and other kettle cooked specialties. The NAICS code for the processes at the facility is 311612.  Many areas of the plant are refrigerated to maintain temperature in the production and storage areas.

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one RMP regulated refrigeration system onsite that is used for refrigerating meat products. The system originally contained a charge of 21,000 pounds of ammonia.  The amount of ammonia currently present in this refrigeration system is approximately 26,000 pounds, which is above the minimum threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds. 

A topographic map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A. An area map is included as Appendix B.

VI.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program. This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The next audit of the PSM program will occur in March of 2006 in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
·	Employee Participation ¿ Otto & Sons has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program ensures employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  Employees at Otto & Sons have assisted in developing the initial PHA for the ammonia process and will participate in updating and revalidating the PHA every five years.  In addition, employees have assisted in the development of other PSM/RMP information such as the development of operating and preventative maintenance procedures.
·	Process Safety Information ¿ Otto & Sons has developed a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining

ive maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Preventative maintenance procedures have been established within written operating procedures dated December 10, 2003. In addition, a preventative maintenance database application has been established to assist in documenting and tracking preventative maintenance activities.
·	Contractor Qualifications ¿ Otto & Sons has developed a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers¿ safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Otto & Sons and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency action plan and control over entrance into process areas.
·	Incident Investigation ¿ Otto & Sons has developed a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure also makes provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 
·	Compliance Audit ¿ The facility completed an original RMP on June 21, 1999 for the ammonia refrigeration system that held a charge of 21,000 pounds of ammonia. The amount of ammonia currently present in the refrigeration system is approximately 26,000 pounds. A compliance audit was conducted on March 7, 2003, and the next compliance audit will be conducted by March 7, 2006.  Otto & Sons has developed a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Otto & Sons¿ PSM/RMP practi

ces and procedures are adequate and are being followed.
·	Hot Work Permits ¿ Otto & Sons has implemented the hot work program and developed a best management practice for hot work.

VII.	Five-Year Accident History
The Otto & Sons facility has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.

VIII. 	Emergency Response Program
Otto & Sons has an Emergency Response Plan (ERP), updated on September 30, 2003, to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. Response activities will be coordinated with the City of Chicago Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), the Chicago Fire Department Station 49. This coordination effort includes providing the fire departments with site diagrams and hazardous material information, meeting with fire department personnel to discuss facility operations/processes, and periodic on-site inspections by fire department personnel.

The facility maintains an ERP on file at the plant. According to the ERP, facility employees are responsible for investigating and assisting the fire department (if necessary) with response to accidental releases of ammonia. The plan includes annual training of all employees on evacuation procedures and emergency notification procedures. The plan also includes annual training for emergency response team members. It identifies the Emergency Response Coordinators, Evacuation Coordinators and alternates. In addition to the facility ERP, the plant is included in a community emergency response plan developed by the City of Chicago Local Emergency Planning Committee. Otto & Sons coordinates with the Chicago Fire Department Station 49 (which includes a HAZMAT Team) on emergency re

sponse activities. 

The facility has a windsock present onsite (located on the top of the building over the engine room) for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release.

Responders receive HAZWOPER training through classroom instruction and drills. HAZWOPER training includes the first responder awareness level, the first responder operations level and hazardous materials technician training.  The facility¿s Maintenance / Facility Engineer also receives incident commander training. Responder HAZWOPER training includes procedures for using and maintaining emergency response equipment as required.

The facility's Onsite Incident Commander or Emergency Response Coordinator (Maintenance / Facility Engineer) is responsible for notifying onsite emergency response personnel, emergency response contractors and local, state and federal agencies of releases. The Emergency Response Coordinator (Maintenance / Facility Engineer)  is also responsible for submitting written communication concerning releases to local, state and federal agencies.

The facility¿s Evacuation Coordinator (Safety Director) is responsible for coordinating site evacuation in the event of a release that requires evacuation.

The facility¿s Emergency Response Plan is maintained onsite as part of the Risk Management Program. 

The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix F. 

IX.	Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are included in the facility¿s Emergency Response Plan.  

X.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Otto & Sons¿ operations. Otto & Sons recently conducted an audit of their Process Safety Management Program and has dutifully implemented the recommendations from that audit. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Otto & Sons. In addition to the facility ERP, the plant is included in a

community emergency response plan developed by the City of Chicago Local Emergency Planning Committee. 

XI.	Management Program
Otto & Sons has developed a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This includes assigning a qualified person (or position) to have overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals need to be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Brent Afman, Plant Manager, is responsible for overall implementation of the Risk Management Program.
